nodes.text: Machine learning methods can be used to predict stock market values and thereby help investors make better buy and sell decisions
This paper uses a systematic literature review (SLR) methodology to collect and synthesize prior research on machine learning for stock market prediction
Inclusion criteria required papers be in English, fully available, and relevant to stock market prediction; quality assessment evaluated authors contributions
Search process screened 550 initial papers by title, abstract, and full text, yielding 45 included papers

Researchers have applied a set of supervised and unsupervised machine learning algorithms to stock prediction, including linear regression, neural networks, genetic algorithms, support vector machines, k-nearest neighbor, and random forest

Prediction accuracy depends on the choice of attributes/features and training data; common attributes include market history, news/events, social media (Twitter), commodity and macroeconomic factors, technical indicators, and exchange rates
Combining event knowledge or news information with machine learning models, particularly neural networks, increases prediction accuracy (reported improvement around five percent in cited experiments)
Support vector machines (SVM) have been reported by multiple studies to perform well for next-day stock movement prediction and to outperform some other classifiers in comparative studies
Random forest has been reported as a strong classifier in some studies, with one cited work claiming 83 percent accuracy for difficult markets and another reporting 64 percent accuracy
A study using multiple classifiers reported an overall accuracy of 65 percent and noted accuracy can be improved with better attributes and larger training data sets
The reviewed literature concludes that more accurate stock predictions can increase investor profit, help sellers and brokers, and inform decisions about when to buy and sell
Stock market prediction remains challenging due to dynamic price changes and many external events that affect prices, making perfect prediction difficult
Effective model training requires historical datasets composed of relevant variables; larger datasets and inclusion of impactful factors improve model performance

Different algorithms have task-specific properties: linear regression predicts continuous values, neural networks can incorporate social media/news features, genetic algorithms and k-NN have been applied for direction prediction and timing
